channel.title: princess pengy!
channel.description: scrawlings of an earthbound spacething about all the things that make her feel

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Bug Fables: The Everlasting Sapling
item.description:
sometimes a game wears its influences in a searingly bright patch right on its sleeve, and that honesty earns a bit of respect from me. what's so special about bug fables is that it's managed to be an even better game than its inspiration in paper mario the thousand year door! better combat, better characters, better everything!

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Luna's Wandering Stars, by Serenity Forge
item.description:
did you know that hit indie publisher serenity forge has actually kept up a steady output of in-house games for a little over a decade? I didn't! this one caught my eye because it's space-themed and I'm the most predictable bitch alive

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: I Contemplated the Sun of Limbo, by Titouan Millet
item.description:
(3 min read)

sometimes a game is so tiny and vague that I can just kinda spin my wheels for a couple hundred words. this is one of those! enjoy this little tiny bit of art analysis while I work on some of the meatier stuff

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Furi, by The Game Bakers
item.description:
I admire a game that knows exactly what it is, and furi is definitely one of thoseâ€”it's a retro-style boss rush with a satisfying flow of combat and memorable characters to get you into that white-knuckle flow state many people who grew up with video games remember. but it, like a lot of games that game out around its release year of 2016, is mired in some opinions about that kind of gameplay that are a little bit frustrating!

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: review: CURSE/KISS/CUTE Episode 0, by Valerie Halla
item.description:
I'm reviewing something that isn't a video game for once, and it's something I've been looking forward to for a long time. this is a story about identity, about the beautiful messy chaos of life, about the joy of discovering others, and about how huge boobs are actually super cool and we should stop acting like they aren't the coolest thing ever.

read the post here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Slay the Princess, by Black Tabby Games
item.description:
I've always been a capital-r romantic person at heart, and nestled within the folds of this game is a story that resonates with that part of me more than I ever expected. for being a game where you stab and get stabbed by an awful lot of women, it's a beautiful and intricate thing filled with life and love and constant surprises. also my very first encounter was with the stranger, and if you know what that means you probably have an idea of just how hard this game came in swinging.

(13 min read)

read the new diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: I don't think most video essays are actually essays
item.description:
some assorted thoughts on the current state of longform media analysis on the internet, and how I think we really need to stop and think about what we're throwing under the blanket term of "video essay". also I do a bit of post-mortem talk on my own video about inscryption!

read the full post here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: In Stars and Time, by insertdisc5
item.description:
I finally played this one after everybody telling me it's fantastic, but this time, not only did it live up to the hype, it actually surprised me by being better than I expected in basically every way!

also, while writing this, this one got really, really personal. this game isn't fucking around with the mental illness stuff, and it got to me in ways I don't know that I've ever been gotten to before. I talk about some harrowing stuff in this one, but I think it's worth it. this is maybe one of my favorite games I've ever played so far. you should play it, and you should read about it.

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: DARK FOREST VIRTUAL CHATROOM by Heather Flowers & Remember Places? by Bryce Bucher
item.description:
in my years on the internet, I've been made to flee the online spaces I came to see as a sort of home time and time again, whether it's a hostile takeover of an instant messaging program or the brutal execution of an entire sphere of content on a social media platform. in talking about these two games where digital worlds take the spotlight, I also ended up writing a sort of eulogy of all these lost homes. I hope it speaks to you

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Outer Wilds, by Mobius Games
item.description:
suppose nothing can be saved from annihilation. suppose the eye does not want to be found. suppose all that remains is you. suppose there is something beautiful that you will never be able to see. suppose it could not exist without you.

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Frogsong, by Frogteam Games
item.description:
the first blog post in a post-cohost internet, and in the spirit of community, I'm writing about a game from a dear friend of mine that I was recently given the chance to play! behind an unassuming appearance and familiar story, this is a game with a lot of love to give and that tackles just as many big problems as its protagonist, from the consequences of imperialism to dealing with the weight of your loved ones' expectations.

read the full diary entry here!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Anodyne 2: Return to Dust, by Analgesic Productions
item.description:
I actually just finished this game the other day, and the moment I did so I immediately declared "I have to write about this. I'm going to write so goddamn much about this."

anodyne 2 is a game about what it means to live through painÂ¸ and to live with that pain seated tightly in your heart. it's a game that kept surprising me and never settled into a predictable rhythm, yet still beautifully ties everything it has to say together. it's a story that can be appreciated on like ten different levels. I wrote an exhausting amount of words about it but still feel like I have even more to say about it. I hope you play the game, and I hope you enjoy reading about it!

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: A NIGHTMARE'S TRIP, by SKY HOUR WORKS
item.description:
got a fun little visual novel on the docket today! in case the above screenshot didn't make it clear, this one is very online in its sensibilities, but in a way that I can't help but find a little bit endearing. it's also pretty brief, so this summary is pretty brief too!

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Far from Noise, by George Batchelor
item.description:
when I play a game that decides to ask things like what you see in the screenshot above, I release a certain level of restraint in my discussion of it. you have opened the doors of philosophical debate and buddy, there's no turning back now

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: OneShot, by Future Cat
item.description:
I wrote a whole lot of words again. I couldn't help it! this game is just one of the most important things in the whole entire world to me. like I know I'm always telling people yume nikki is my favorite game ever, and it's true, but I don't think anything has rocked me at my core harder than this. it's so important. hopefully I've been able to articulate why

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: The Magic Circle, by Question
item.description:
games about games are nothing new to mid-2010s independent developers, but this is maybe the most about games I've seen a game ever be! so much so that I ended up going a little bit overboard and writing a much longer diary entry than usual and I am not sorry in the slightest

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Bastion, by Supergiant Games
item.description:
feels a little bit odd to be reviewing a game from so long agoâ€”this one's less of a contemporary review and more of a historical curiosity at this point! bastion also mostly makes me want to play transistor again, but I don't think that's really a fault of the game itself. I'm simply a lesbian

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Smile for Me, by LimboLane
item.description:
what a sweet little game! a delightful homage to retro adventure games with that special sense of humor that gradually clings to you like pollen after spending a long enough time on mid-to-late-2010s internet hangouts.

unfortunately, as is proving to be the case with fandom smash hits of around the turn of the decade with a narrative focus on mental illness, I once again regret to inform you that I have Takes about how this game ends up handling that.

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: some thoughts on criticizing good games
item.description:
I feel like as strange gaming diaries has progressed as a series, I find myself more ferociously critical than I am celebratory, which isn't what I envisioned these writing exercises as being like tone-wise when I started. I'm not trying to make a Thing out of elaborate takedowns of years-old independently developed darlings, it just so happens that a lot of the games I played back in 2023 (and am thus spending 2024 catching up on) were games that left me feeling kinda frustrated!

(read the full ramble here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: trange Gaming Diaries: Dreaming Sarah (& Wishing Sarah), by Asteristic Game Studio
item.description:
I love it when a game proudly and explicitly calls itself "inspired by yume nikki" so I have yet another opportunity to talk about my favorite video game. the two games themselves are a bit of a mixed bagâ€”unsurprising given the well they're drawing fromâ€”but it gives me the perfect chance to talk about surreal themes in games, and why "there is a big eyeball and it is staring at you" does not the style of yume nikki make

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: 2000:1: A Space Felony, by National Insecurities
item.description:
a delightful little scifi yarn in which you're a detective trying to piece together a murder case on board a space station. not solve a murder case, mind you; the prime suspect is a faceless AI named MAL. the perpetrator couldn't really be more obvious here

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: OMORI, by OMOCAT
item.description:
so there I was, playing The RPG Maker Game About Depression in its final form. I saw it through to the end and enjoyed it the whole time. but, despite it all, the only lingering feeling I have towards it is a gnawing pit of frustration in my chest. if you'll allow me, let me maybe try to elaborate on why that is!

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Boa Retina, by Jennifer Raye
item.description:
one more move of all of my personal belongings later, and I'm back! this time I'm talking about a game jennifer raye made that absolutely destroyed me in a way nothing else has. this one might get more rambley and less cohesive than the other diary entries, but that's okay. it feels fitting that way

(read the full diary entry here!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: Serre, by insertdisc5
item.description:
a while back I played serre by @insertdisc5, who has apparently in the intervening time made another game that's had quite a lot of buzz! nothing will beat the amount of buzz in this game though. heh. get it cuz. cuz she's a bee. cuz there's a bee in it. heheh.

anyway if the truly volcanic amount of sapphic tension in the above image is as to your liking as it is mine, give the game a shot and feel free to give my review a read!
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: THE ENIGMA MACHINE, by ENIGMA STUDIO
item.description:
do you want to peer inside the mind of an artificial intelligence? this game gives you a chance to do just that! (no but like, seriously, are you REALLY sure you want to do thatâ€¦?)

(click here for the full blog post!)
item.author: pengy

item.title: Strange Gaming Diaries: The Hex, by Daniel Mullins Games
item.description:
from the maker of other games you've probably heard about comes an eccentric and experimental thing about game development and the perils thereof. even better than its sibling games in a regard or two, daring I may be to say it!

(click here for the full blog post!)
item.author: pengy
